DOC.HEAD: Police Official Ordered Jailed in Fraud Case

Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Magistrate Virginia...', to add possible maximum sentence, Weiner's age; SUBS 12th graf, `The fraud...', with 3 grafs to add more detail on Thursday testimony, background. Picks up 13th graf, `Weiner said...'.
DOC.TEXT: A former police official accused of defrauding investors and of stealing from the department was ordered jailed to keep him from fleeing before his next court appearance. Kenneth Weiner, former deputy chief of the Detroit Police Department, was arrested early Thursday at Detroit Metropolitan Airport. He was carrying dozens of charge cards, airline flight coupons, a passport and $3,100 in Canadian money, FBI agents testified at Weiner's U.S. District Court bond hearing. Magistrate Virginia M. Morgan sent Weiner, 43, to jail without bond on a federal fraud charge until his pretrial hearing Jan. 2. The charge, which carries a possible sentence of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine, stems from his alleged involvement in a scheme to defraud investors of $20 million. Morgan said Weiner has an ability to manipulate the system, to appear or disappear whenever it was in his interest to do so. Weiner's attorney, Robert Harrison, said an appeal will be filed immediately but acknowledged Weiner likely will be held until after Christmas. `He's very unhappy right now, obviously,'' Harrison said outside the courtroom. ``He feels the truth did not come out.'' Harrison said the flood of media reports on the mystery of Weiner's whereabouts in the past few weeks tainted the case, making Weiner appear evasive. ``He's a man who travels in his own name all over the country,'' Harrison said. He said Weiner was flying to Detroit from Los Angeles to meet with his attorneys regarding an Internal Revenue Service investigation. Police Chief William Hart recently accused Weiner of stealing from a $1.4 million Detroit police secret service fund used for undercover operations. Weiner had access to the fund from 1980 to 1986. FBI Agent Thomas Cannistra, who has been investigating Weiner since May 1986, testified Thursday that Weiner sent $1.3 million from the secret service fund to dummy corporations in California. Federal investigators have said that two of the corporations named by Cannistra paid a $3,000 monthly rent bill for a house in Beverly Hills, Calif., occupied for two years by Hart's daughter and son-in-law. Hart has denied knowing about the rent payments. Cannistra said the fraud charge is unrelated to the police investigation but is from a pyramid investment scheme involving the sale of gold and silver. He said between $5 million and $10 million remains missing from the scheme. Weiner's court troubles began in 1986 when Caine Steel Co. of Detroit filed a civil suit against him, charging that he defrauded the company of $379,000. He was accused of duping as many as 90 investors out of about $20 million in a scheme that involved trading of gold and silver. The alleged investment scheme used new investors' cash to provide large returns to previous investors. Such plans collapse when new investors can't be found.
